001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A relatively simple {@link IPointHash} that multiplies each of the x, y, etc. components and the state by a different
005 * constant for each (a "harmonious number" related to the golden ratio), sums them, and keeps only the upper bits.
006 * This benefits from dot-product optimizations performed by recent JVMs (since at least Java 8). It finishes each hash
007 * with an XLCG step to improve the upper bits, then it right-shifts the whole long so it fits in the desired output
008 * range (such as 8 bits for {@link #hash256(int, int, int)}), casts it to int and returns that.
009 * <br>
010 * This hash is slightly faster for some noise applications than {@link IntPointHash}, and has comparable quality, but
011 * does require a lot of math on long values, and that can be quite slow on GWT. This should probably be used primarily
012 * on desktop targets, and/or maybe mobile.
013 */
014public final class GoldPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
015
016    public static final GoldPointHash INSTANCE = new GoldPointHash();
017
018    @Override
019    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
020        return hashAll(x, y, state);
021    }
022
023    @Override
024    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
025        return hashAll(x, y, z, state);
026    }
027
028    @Override
029    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
030        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
031    }
032
033    @Override
034    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
035        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
036    }
037
038    @Override
039    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
040        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
041    }
042
043    /**
044     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
045     * @param x x position, as an int
046     * @param y y position, as an int
047     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
048     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
049     */
050    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int s) {
051        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
052    }
053    /**
054     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
055     * @param x x position, as an int
056     * @param y y position, as an int
057     * @param z z position, as an int
058     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
059     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
060     */
061    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
062        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
063    }
064
065    /**
066     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
067     * @param x x position, as an int
068     * @param y y position, as an int
069     * @param z z position, as an int
070     * @param w w position, as an int
071     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
072     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
073     */
074    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
075        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
076                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
077    }
078
079    /**
080     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
081     * @param x x position, as an int
082     * @param y y position, as an int
083     * @param z z position, as an int
084     * @param w w position, as an int
085     * @param u u position, as an int
086     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
087     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state s
088     */
089    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int s) {
090        return (int)((0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL * x + 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL * y + -0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L * z +
091                0xA6F5777F6F88983FL * w + -0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL * u + 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL * s ^
092                0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
093    }
094
095    /**
096     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
097     * @param x x position, as an int
098     * @param y y position, as an int
099     * @param z z position, as an int
100     * @param w w position, as an int
101     * @param u u position, as an int
102     * @param v v position, as an int
103     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
104     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
105     */
106    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
107        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
108                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v +
109                -0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
110    }
111
112    /**
113     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
114     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
115     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
116     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
117     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
118     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
119     * @param x x position, as an int
120     * @param y y position, as an int
121     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
122     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
123     */
124    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int s) {
125        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
126    }
127    /**
128     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
129     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
130     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
131     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
132     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
133     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
134     * @param x x position, as an int
135     * @param y y position, as an int
136     * @param z z position, as an int
137     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
138     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
139     */
140    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
141        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
142    }
143
144    /**
145     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
146     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
147     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
148     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
149     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
150     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
151     * @param x x position, as an int
152     * @param y y position, as an int
153     * @param z z position, as an int
154     * @param w w position, as an int
155     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
156     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
157     */
158    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
159        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
160                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
161    }
162
163    /**
164     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
165     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
166     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
167     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
168     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
169     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
170     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
171     * @param x x position, as an int
172     * @param y y position, as an int
173     * @param z z position, as an int
174     * @param w w position, as an int
175     * @param u u position, as an int
176     * @param v v position, as an int
177     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
178     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
179     */
180    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
181        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
182                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
183                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
184    }
185
186    /**
187     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
188     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
189     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
190     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
191     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
192     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
193     * @param x x position, as an int
194     * @param y y position, as an int
195     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
196     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
197     */
198    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int s) {
199        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
200    }
201    /**
202     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
203     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
204     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
205     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
206     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
207     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
208     * @param x x position, as an int
209     * @param y y position, as an int
210     * @param z z position, as an int
211     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
212     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
213     */
214    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
215        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
216    }
217
218    /**
219     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
220     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
221     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
222     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
223     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
224     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
225     * @param x x position, as an int
226     * @param y y position, as an int
227     * @param z z position, as an int
228     * @param w w position, as an int
229     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
230     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
231     */
232    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
233        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
234                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
235    }
236
237    /**
238     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
239     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
240     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
241     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
242     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
243     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
244     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
245     * @param x x position, as an int
246     * @param y y position, as an int
247     * @param z z position, as an int
248     * @param w w position, as an int
249     * @param u u position, as an int
250     * @param v v position, as an int
251     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
252     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
253     */
254    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
255        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
256                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
257                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
258    }
259    /**
260     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
261     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
262     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
263     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
264     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
265     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
266     * @param x x position, as an int
267     * @param y y position, as an int
268     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
269     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
270     */
271    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int s) {
272        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
273    }
274    /**
275     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
276     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
277     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
278     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
279     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
280     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
281     * @param x x position, as an int
282     * @param y y position, as an int
283     * @param z z position, as an int
284     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
285     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
286     */
287    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
288        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
289    }
290
291    /**
292     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
293     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
294     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
295     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
296     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
297     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.

303     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
304     */
305    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {

308    }

310    /**
311     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
312     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
313     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
314     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
315     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
316     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
317     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
318     * @param x x position, as an int
319     * @param y y position, as an int
320     * @param z z position, as an int
321     * @param w w position, as an int
322     * @param u u position, as an int
323     * @param v v position, as an int
324     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
325     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
326     */
327    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
328        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
329                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
330                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
331    }
